sections.heading: One-pot Fabrication of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au Nano-alloy Using Cellulosic
Solid Support for Catalytic Reduction Application

Graphical abstract

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
Manufacture of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au bimetallic nano-alloy was carried out and
deposited directly onto cellulose solid support.
 AuNPs and AgNPs were obtained in size of 26.1 nm and 36.3 nm, respectively.  The reduction of p-nitroaniline was frequently speeded up in the presence of AuNPs,
AgNPs and Ag-Au.
 By using Ag-Au, 87.2% from p-nitro-aniline was turned into p-phenylene-di-amine only
in 20 minutes.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
The current report provides a simple, green and inexpensive route for one-pot fabrication
of AgNPs, AuNPs, and Ag-Au nano-alloy individually onto cellulosic solid support. Cellulosic solid support was naturally extracted from plant and then was used for deposition of nanoparticles. The manufacturing was carried out through redox reaction between metal ions and alcoholic groups of cellulose, resulting in production of metallic/bimetallic nanostructures. AuNPs was obtained in size of 26.1 nm smaller than AgNPs (36.3 nm). Controlling in size of bimetallic nanostructures was achieved by tuning the concentrations, mass ratios of nanometal precursors and their addition sequencing in reaction liquor. Immobilization of nanoparticles/bimetallic nanostructures was frequently speeded up the reduction reaction of p-nitro-aniline, however,
bimetallic nanostructures exhibited much better catalytic reactivity, where, 87.2% from p-nitroaniline was reduced to p-phenylene-di-amine only in 20 minutes in the presence of Ag-Au bimetallic nano-alloy.
Keywords: Cellulose, AgNPs, AuNPs, Ag-Au nano-alloy, Catalytic activity.
1. INTRODUCTION
Due to their unique optical (Wilcoxon & Abrams, 2006), electronic (Moskalenko et al.,
2009), and catalytic activities (Bond, 1999; M. Chen & Goodman, 2006; Daniel & Astruc, 2004), manufacturing of metal nanoparticles (NPs) has been increasingly studied. In particular, silver and gold nanoparticles (AgNPs & AuNPs) are the most prepared NPs owing to their major role in biochemistry, biology and medicine (Homberger & Simon, 2010; Jain, Huang, El-Sayed, & ElSayed, 2008; Sperling, Gil, Zhang, Zanella, & Parak, 2008). Relatively, monometallic and bimetallic nanostructures have wide range of applications due to their additional degrees of freedom, which improved their optical and catalytic properties (J. Huang et al., 2009; Y.-C. Liu, Yu, & Hsu, 2007). The change in composition of metals, reaction conditions and molar masses of metal salts provides bimetallic nanostructures with different dimension, shape and size which act in tailoring the acquired properties (L. Sun, Luan, & Shan, 2012). Depending on the reaction conditions and mechanism; bimetallic nanostructures may be manufactured with one or more of the following geometrical structures, random, cluster-in-cluster, core-shell and alloy structures. In random structure, atoms are arranged haphazardly. Cluster-in-cluster structure, one element type forms nanoclusters and the other acts as binder. In core-shell structure, one metal is synthesized firstly in reaction medium to form the core, while the other metal is formed later as the outer shell. In alloy structure, two metal nanoparticles are supposed to be manufactured in reaction liquor with nearly the same rate. Also, for bulk metals, two kinds of elements often provide nanoalloys, where, elements with similar atomic sizes form a random alloy, while that with different atomic sizes form inter-metallic alloy (Y. Yang, Shi, Kawamura, & Nogami, 2008).
Manufacturing of alloyed bimetallic NPs are widely studied because of, they provide some
of opportunities to exploit unique properties of metal nanoparticles (X. Liu, Wang, Wang, Mou,
& Zhang, 2008; A.-Q. Wang, Chang, & Mou, 2005; A.-Q. Wang, Liu, Lin, Lin, & Mou, 2005; C. Wang, Yin, et al., 2009). The Au-AgNPs alloy is particularly considered in numerous of recent researches due to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) peak is tunable between nearly 520 nm for Au (Daniel & Astruc, 2004) and nearly 410 nm for Ag (Bright, Musick, & Natan, 1998). Ag/Au alloyed nanoparticles could combine the physical and chemical properties of both nanometals. Also, small sized bimetallic nanostructures were reported to be auto-fluorescent (Ristig, Kozlova, Meyer-Zaika, & Epple, 2014; L. Yang, Shang, & Nienhaus, 2013) and biosensors rather than individual nanometals (J. Huang et al., 2009; Y.-C. Liu et al., 2007). Therefore, preparation of controllable sized nano-alloys of Ag-Au with precise composition and high surface activity is still of a great challenge.
Synthetic methodologies including wet chemical synthesis by co-reduction of Au and Ag
salts with citrate (Link, Wang, & El-Sayed, 1999; Pal, Shah, Kulkarni, Murthy, & Devi, 2009), NaBH4 (Petkov et al., 2014) or starch and glucose (Raveendran, Fu, & Wallen, 2006), reduction with hydrazine in water-oil emulsions (D.-H. Chen & Chen, 2002), sol–gel processes (Devarajan, Bera, & Sampath, 2005) or UV irradiation (Gonzalez, Liu, & Scaiano, 2009) were presented lately in literatures. Most of manufacturing methodologies were relied on complex formation which is also, high in costing and depended on the use of strong ligands as stabilizers for alloyed nanostructures (C. Wang, Yin, et al., 2009). Whereas, the co-reduction was described as the preferable method for manufacturing of Au-Ag nano alloy which is depending on the usage different reducers and protecting agents (Burda, Chen, Narayanan, & El-Sayed, 2005; Oko et al., 2014; C. Wang, Yin, et al., 2009).
The large scaled approaches for manufacturing of metal nanostructures give the researchers
different of options for the selection of optimal parameters and the synthesis of given product for certain applications. Using of supporting/insoluble polymers to act as a template in manufacturing of metal nanoparticles are recently considered, because of the synergistic properties of the nanometal/polymer composites, derived from responsive polymer and metallic nanoparticles (Thomas, Namdeo, Murali Mohan, Bajpai, & Bajpai, 2007). The type of nanometal/polymer composites have shown a promising potential for using as solid/hybrid materials in biomedical applications (Palza, 2015), sensing (Han, Zhang, & Serpe, 2015), and catalytic reactions (Ballauff & Lu, 2007).
Like monometallic, bimetallic nanostructures which are pre-manufactured in colloidal
solutions can be further deposited on a support, but their original structure, size distribution and topographical features are hardly retained (X. Liu, Wang, Yang, et al., 2008). Therefore, it would be more preferable to combine the manufacturing and deposition of bimetallic nanoparticles onto a certain template in a one step, concurrently. This reflects the importance and urgency to develop an in-situ synthesis strategy of bimetallic structures within suitable supporting templates. Taking in consideration that, it is extremely important to develop effective eco-friendly and cost-efficient methods for concurrent manufacturing.
Hence, in the current work, AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au bimetallic NPs were individually
fabricated and directly deposited onto cellulose solid support via an effective, green, inexpensive and reproducible pathway. Cellulose solid support was extracted from Eichhornia crassipes stem and was then used as template for all the mentioned nanostructures. The successive role of cellulosic solid support in manufacturing the different mentioned NPs was confirmed through the instrumental characterization of the so-obtained NPs using SEM, XRD, and FTIR mapping data. Size distribution of the so-produced nanostructures was estimated from SEM and XRD micrographs. Metal and carboxyl content for cellulose was measured for confirming the redox reaction between cellulosic macromolecules and metals precursors for manufacturing the different nanostructures. Several key parameters of the presented strategy were investigated, to show the important role of concentration, mass ratios and addition sequencing of Ag and Au salts for constructing the alloyed bimetallic nanostructures. Catalytic reactivity of the so-produced nanostructures was examined for p-nitro-aniline reduction by action of sodium borohydride and the kinetics of the catalytic properties were measured.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and Chemicals:
sections.text:
Silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99.5%, from Panreac, Barcelona – Spain), Gold chloride (AuCL3,
99%, from, Bombay – India), Sodium hydroxide (99%, from Merck, Darmstadt–Germany), Nitric acid (55%, from the Egyptian company for chemicals and pharmaceuticals, 10th of Ramadan – Egypt), p-nitroaniline (C6H6N2O2, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich, Darmstadt – Germany), Sodium
borohydride (98%, from RFCL limited, New Delhi – India) were all used without any further purification. Water hyacinth plants (Eichhornia crassipes) were collected from fresh water canals at El-Marg region, Delta, Egypt in May.

sections.heading: 2.2. Extraction process:
sections.text:
Water hyacinth plant was washed well with running tap water and kept on filter paper to
reduce the water content and left to dry for one week under sunlight conditions. Stems of the plants were taken and cut into small pieces and then dried in oven at 70 °C for 2 hrs. Finally, it was grinded to a powder form and was then sieved. The resultant powder of water hyacinth was treated with 2% (w/w) sodium hydroxide solution at 100 °C under mechanical stirring for 4 hrs. The mixture was filtered and washed several times with distilled water until the alkali was completely removed and finally dried at 60 °C for 12 hrs in an air circulating oven. This process was repeated for another time and then further grinding was carried out. After the treatment, the powder was bleached with a solution containing hydrogen peroxide (5 g/L of 45 % H2O2) and sodium silicate (3 g/L) at pH 10.5 (adjusted by using aqueous NaOH) using 1:20 liquor ratio and reaction proceeded for 30 min at 95 °C. At the end, the bleached powder was washed for several times with distilled water until neutralization, subsequently dried at room temperature and then grinded using a mill (El-Zawahry, Abdelghaffar, Abdelghaffar, & Hassabo, 2016; El-Zawahry, Abdelghaffar, Abdelghaffar, & Mashaly, 2016).

sections.heading: 2.3. Chemical compositions of the extracted powder:
sections.text:
The chemical composition of the treated powder was determined for three times and the
mean average was added in supplementary data. Lignin content was determined directly using the traditional method reported in literature (El-Zawahry, Abdelghaffar, Abdelghaffar, & Hassabo, 2016; El-Zawahry, Abdelghaffar, Abdelghaffar, & Mashaly, 2016). Contents of α-cellulose and hemicellulose in the extracted powder were measured according to reference (Jayme, 1942). Holocellulose is the total carbohydrate fraction (cellulose and hemicellulose) and was estimated according to reported method (Wise, Murphy, & D ADIECO, 1946). The ash content was estimated by using TAPPI method (Ehrman, 1994). The isolated powder was found to be composed of 69.3 % α – cellulose, 21.2 % hemicellulose, 2.6 % lignin and 1.5 % ash content. The cellulosic components (α – cellulose & hemicellulose) were represented ca. 90.5 % from the total
extraction. The percentage of holocellulose as the total carbohydrates content was 95.9 % which already included cellulosic components (90.5 %) and thus the estimated insoluble carbohydrates content was ca. 5.4 %. The extracted powder was named as cellulosic solid support (CSS) owing to their compositions which are mainly cellulosic components. The cellulosic solid support was used as template for direct deposition of monometallic (Ag & Au) and bimetallic (Ag-Au) nanostructures.

sections.heading: 2.4. Procedure:
sections.text:
Deposition of metal and bimetal nanoparticles onto cellulosic solid support (CSS) was
carried out directly in one step process. In this technique, a 0.2 g of CSS was added to 50 mL of 0.1 N NaOH, then the temperature was raised to 80 ± 5 °C under continuous stirring. For deposition of either AgNPs or AuNPs, after 10 minutes, metal salt was added drop wisely and the reaction was performed for 30 minute with stirring. In case of preparing alloyed bimetallic nanoparticles, addition of the first metal salt was carried out and the reaction was conducted for 30 minutes at the same temperature then the other metal salt was added and the reaction was preceded for further 30 minutes. Concentrations of metal salts and their sequence of additions were illustrated in Table 1. At the end of processing, metal containing cellulose was collected by filtration and dried in oven at 80 ± 5 °C for 4 h prior to analyses and characterizations.

sections.heading: 2.5.1. Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX)
sections.text:
Metal containing cellulose was detected by high resolution scanning electron microscopy
(SEM Quanta FEG 250 with field emission gun, FEI Company – Netherlands). The chemical composition of the manufactured composites was analyzed using surface Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (EDAX AMETEK analyzer) attached with the electron microscope. Size of nanometal particles and the alloyed bimetallic nanoparticles was calculated from microscopic images by using software of 4 pi analysis.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. X-ray Diffraction (XRD)
sections.text:
CSS and metal containing cellulose were both analyzed by X-ray diffraction using
diffractometer system from Philips (X’Pert MPP with a type PW 3050⁄10 goniometer) at room temperature. Diffraction patterns were detected in the diffraction angle (2θ) range of 10° - 80° using a PC computer with the programs PROFIT and monochromatized (Mo Kα X-radiation at 40 kV, 50 mA and λ = 0.70930 Å) with a step size of 0.03°.

sections.heading: 2.5.3. FTIR
sections.text:
Infrared spectra were examined for both of CSS and metal containing cellulose using infrared
Spectrometer (Jasco FT/IR 6100) conducted to detector of deuterated triglycine sulfate (TGS). The spectra were collected in range of 4000 – 400 cm–1 using transmission mode (T%), resolution of 4 cm–1 with 1 cm-1 interval scanning and scanning speed of 2 mm/sec.

sections.heading: 2.5.4. Detection of metal contents
sections.text:
Silver was firstly extracted from CSS by submerging 0.1 g of cellulose in 20 mL of 15 %
nitric acid at 80 °C for 2 h. Ag contents in the extracted solutions were measured with flame atomic absorption spectrophotometer (Agilent 200 series AA systems, 240FS AA, Agilent technologies, USA) attached with GTA 120 graphite tube atomizer. While Au contents were measured from EDX spectra.

sections.heading: 2.5.5. Carboxylic content
sections.text:
Carboxyl contents of CSS before and after nanoparticles deposition were measured using
the methylene blue dye method (Emam & El-Bisi, 2014; Emam, Manian, et al., 2014). A 25 mL from methylene blue solution (300 mg/L) was added to 25 mL of borate buffer solution (pH= 8.5) in a 50 mL bottle contains cellulose powder (0.05 – 0.1 g) and the mixture was shaken for 20 h at room temperature. A 2.5 mL of the mixture was transported to 50 mL measuring flask contains a 5 mL of HCl solution (0.1 M) and then the total volume was filled up to 50 mL by distilled water. The absorbance of solutions was measured using double beam Spectrophotometer (6800 UV/Vis, d= 10 mm, Jenway – UK) at λmax of methylene blue (664.5 nm). Series of methylene blue solutions with concentrations in the range of 1–10 mg/L was prepared at pH 8.5 as calibration solutions. The
slope of calibration curve was used to calculate the COOH content by using Eq. 1. For each sample, two repetitions were performed and the average was considered.

Where, COOH is the carboxyl content of CSS (mmol/g), C1= concentration of methylene blue in the blank (sample without CSS) (mg/L), C2 = concentration of methylene blue in the samples (in presence of CSS) (mg/L), W = mass of CSS samples (g) and MC is the moisture content (%).

sections.heading: 2.6. Catalytic reduction study:
sections.text:
The efficiency of the prepared AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy in the catalytic
activity was tested toward reduction of p-nitro-aniline. Catalytic reduction process was carried out as follows: 10 mg of nanoparticles deposited cellulose was accurately weighed and transferred to 20 mL glass vessel contained 16 mL distilled water. To this mixture, 2 mL of p-nitro-aniline (2 mM) and 2 mL of NaBH4 (150 mM) were added. After immediate addition of NaBH4, the absorbance of solutions was measured using multichannel spectrophotometer (T80 UV/VIS, d= 10 mm, PG Instruments Ltd, Japan) up to 120 minutes’ reaction time.

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS AND DISSCUSION
sections.text:
A number of traditional strategies have been studied for the preparation of monometallic
nanoclusters and alloyed bimetallic nanostructures (Gonzalez et al., 2009; Raveendran et al., 2006; Sharma & Gupta, 2005; C. Wang, Peng, Chan, & Sun, 2009). However, most of these procedures have been carried out for manufacturing in a colloidal phase (Gonzalez et al., 2009; Raveendran et al., 2006; Sharma & Gupta, 2005). Mostly, for manipulating and processing these nanoparticles for practical applications such as optoelectronics, catalytic activity and sensor devices, embedding within polymer matrixes, or on solid substrates was extremely required (Alqudami, Annapoorni, & Shivaprasad, 2008; Sharma & Gupta, 2005).
According to the nucleation and growth model of nanometal atoms on polymeric surfaces
shown in literatures (Ahmed, Abdel-Mohsen, & Emam, 2016; Ahmed, Zahran, & Emam, 2016; El-Rafie, Ahmed, & Zahran, 2014; Emam & Ahmed, 2016; Emam, El-Rafie, Ahmed, & Zahran,
(1)
2015; Emam, Mowafi, Mashaly, & Rehan, 2014; Emam, Saleh, Nagy, & Zahran, 2015, 2016; Emam & Zahran, 2015; Hebeish, El-Rafie, Abdel-Mohdy, Abdel-Halim, & Emam, 2010; Zahran, Ahmed, & El-Rafie, 2014a, 2014b), metal atoms initially adsorbed on the polymeric macromolecules, then nucleation started in reactor bath, as the growth of metal nanoparticles on polymeric building blocks started by adsorption of small nuclei at certain sites which is supposed to grow with continuous deposition of nanometals by direct impingement. For alloyed MNPs, silver and gold were deposited simultaneously, and a complete alloy is expected to be manufactured as gold and silver are in the same group of periodic table and have the same structures and similar atomic radius which might be resulted in full miscibility within a solid phase.
Hence, the presented protocol offered a simple and controllable method for one-pot
fabrication of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au bimetallic nano-alloy onto cellulosic powder as a plant extract natural biopolymer. The technique used can be easily applicable for further manufacturing of other bimetallic or multi-metallic nanoparticles. Cellulosic backbone plays a dual role of both reducing agent (nano-structures generator) and stabilizer for the produced nanostructures. The reaction variables such as metal salts concentrations, mass ratios of nanometal precursors and their addition sequencing in reaction liquor were all studied to control the size distributions of the obtained nanostructures.
SEM micrographs, EDX analysis and size distribution
The aptitude of the current synthetic strategy in manufacturing of AgNPs, AuNPs and
bimetallic Ag-Au nanostructures using cellulosic solid support, was displayed using SEM and EDX data. The topographical features of the prepared samples were investigated by micrographs and were presented in Figures 1 and 2. The micrographs of monometallic specimens (Fig. 1b & 1d) viewed the immediate deposition of AgNPs and AuNPs. Besides, EDX analysis in the corresponding figures detected that, Ag and Au signals were separately viewed, which confirming the successful deposition of AgNPs and AuNPs individually on the surface of CSS. As reported in literature, when the mass ratio of metal salts is 1:1, Au-Ag core-shell bimetallic nanostructures were obtained (L. Sun et al., 2012). But formation of core-shell bimetallic structures is excluded in the current work owing to its solid phase. Lack of apparent core-shell structures supported the notion that, the formed bimetallic nanostructures within the cellulosic macromolecules were mainly in the form of alloys rather than core-shell like shape. Additionally, because of Ag and Au
have similar lattice constants and can be produced in the form of homogeneous alloys in a bulky phase, the formation of alloy nanostructures was expected.
In case of using Ag: Au with 1:1 mass ratio, well dispersed/bimetallic Ag-Au nano-
structures were successfully deposited on the surface of CSS. When Au salt was added firstly to reaction liquor, enlarged bimetallic nanostructures was produced (Fig.1e) compared to that prepared by the addition of Ag salt firstly. Addition of the two metal salts at the same time with the same mass ratios produced more massive deposits with significant bigger size. SEM results revealed that, the addition sequencing and different mass ratios of metal salts are both affected on controlling the nucleation and growth of bimetallic nanoclusters.
Size distribution and mean size of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloys which were
deposited on cellulose, were measured from SEM micrographs and data was diagrammed in Figure 2 and summarized in Table 2. The data revealed that, both of AgNPs and AuNPs was successfully deposited on the surface of CSS, and the so-obtained nanostructures were predominantly well dispersed and small in size. In monometallic nanostructures, AgNPs and AuNPs exhibited a size distribution of 10-60 nm and 10-40 nm, respectively. This surveillance confirmed the role of cellulosic macromolecules in acting as scaffolds for both of AgNPs and AuNPs. Manufacturing of AuNPs in smaller particle size (26.1 nm) compared to AgNPs (36.3 nm) is due to the difference in redox potentials between gold and silver (Y. Sun & Xia, 2002).
In case of alloyed bimetallic nanostructures, whatever the addition sequencing of metal
salts to the reaction mixture, Ag-Au nano-alloys were exhibited nearly the same size distribution (24-52 nm) and mean size (39.5 – 40 nm) using metal salts with 1:1 mass ratio. For unequal mass ratios of metal salts, the data in (Table 2 & Figure 2) indicated that, regardless to the addition sequencing, the concentration of metal salts as generators of nanostructures have more significance effect on the size distribution of so-produced nano-alloys.
The addition of Ag salt firstly to the reaction medium, with mass ratio of 0.25:1 Ag: Au
resulted in synthesis of smaller sized nano-alloys (9.5 nm) rather than that of mass ratio 1:0.25 Ag: Au (13.5 nm). However, in case of adding Au firstly to reaction medium, sample prepared by using of mass ratio 0.25:1 Au: Ag was uploaded by nano-alloys with wider size distribution (3-33 nm) and larger average size (12.5 nm) compared to that synthesized with molar ratio 1:0.25 Au: Ag (5- 17 nm / 10.2 nm). Monitoring of size distribution for the deposited nano-alloys gave rise that, regardless to the addition sequencing, using of higher concentrated Ag salt resulted in manufacturing of bimetallic nano-alloy enlarged in size. On the other hand, addition sequencing of metal salts to the reaction mixture is not significantly affected on the mean size of the manufactured nano-alloys, except in case of adding both metal salts together, in which massive deposits of Ag-Au alloy in micro size were recorded (638 nm).

sections.heading: XRD patterns
sections.text:
CSS and metal nanoparticles containing cellulose were characterized by XRD analyses and
results introduced in Figure 3a. The pristine CSS exhibited two intense diffraction peaks at 2θ= 15.2° and 22.4° which are referred to (101) and (002) lattice planes of cellulose I (Abdelhameed, Abdel-Gawad, Elshahat, & Emam, 2016; Ahmed & Emam, 2016; Emam & Bechtold, 2015; Emam et al., 2016). These diffractions are quite identical for cellulose macromolecules and hence confirm that the extracted powder was almost formed from cellulosic materials which is further supported the cellulose contents results. By deposition of monometallic (AgNPs or AuNPs) onto CSS, crystalline structure of cellulose (cellulose I) was changed to amorphous (cellulose II) as the peaks intensity of cellulose I were obviously decreased. In case of bimetallic deposition, the decrement in intensity of such peaks was significant. The change of cellulose state from crystalline to amorphous is attributed to immediate deposition of bimetallic nanostructures resulting from redox reaction between cellulose macromolecules and metal ions. Owing to the low concentrations of
the used metal salts, non-notable decrement in peak intensity of cellulose I was observed (supplementary data).
For AgNPs containing cellulose, new diffraction peak was recorded at 2θ= 38.2° which is
assigned to (111) face centered cubic (FCC) structure of Ag nanometal. This peak is identically coinciding with that reported in diffraction data of international center (JCPDS data number 04- 0783 card) (Lee et al., 2010; Viana, Mohallem, Miquita, Balzuweit, & Silva-Pinto, 2013). Additional peaks were appeared at scattering angles (2θ) = 38.2°, 44.1°, 64.8° and 77.4° in case of AuNPs containing cellulose. These peaks are related to (111), (200), (220) and (311) FCC structure of metallic gold (JCPDS data number 04-0784 card) (Jiang, Wang, & Chen, 2007; Litvin & Minaev, 2014; Zhang et al., 2004). However, in specimens of bimetallic deposits, both diffraction peaks of Ag and Au were recorded, reflecting the existence of both of them in bimetallic forms. The intensity of Ag and Au diffraction peaks was diminished by using the low concentrated metal salts (supplementary material) which is a result of low deposited metal content. The immediate addition of both metal salts is accompanied by lower intense diffraction beaks for both metals which might be attributed to random and non-uniform deposition of bimetallic nanostructures.
XRD patterns was used to calculate the average size of particles. Firstly, the broadening in
diffraction peaks reflecting that, the considered nanostructures were manufactured with small particle size (Ahmed & Emam, 2016). The main size of so-produced nanostructures (Ag, Au and Ag-Au alloy) was counted via analyzing the diffraction of base peak (111) at 2θ = 38.2° using Debye Scherrer equation (Eq. 2). The particles size of mono and bimetallic calculated from XRD patterns was observed located in the range of size distribution measured from micrographs (Table 3). Considering with the standard errors values, similar particle size to that measured from SEM was obtained from XRD patterns, and this supported the size distribution data measured from SEM micrographs.

sections.heading: FTIR
sections.text:
Monitoring the redox reaction between metal ions and cellulosic solid support for
manufacturing of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au bimetallic nanostructures could be achieved through, the detection of the change in the molecular structure of cellulosic backbone, which in turn could be represented in the data recorded by attenuated total reflection – Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) in Figure 3b. For native extracted powder, a broad absorption band was observed at 3410 cm-1 corresponding to the O-H stretching of cellulose carboxylic group. Absorption band of C-H asymmetric stretching vibration was appeared at 2920 - 2840 cm-1. Carbonyl group of cellulose was recorded at 1641 cm-1. Absorption band at 1440 cm-1 is assigned to H-C-H scissoring, while symmetric bending of C-C was noticed at 1100 cm-1. IR spectrum of the extracted powder is analogous to that for cellulose (Abdelhameed et al., 2016; Ahmed & Emam, 2016; Emam & Bechtold, 2015) which further proves that the extracted powder is mainly cellulosic materials.
In case of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au bimetallic nanostructures loaded upon CSS,
aforementioned characteristic peaks of native cellulose were showed with significant decrement in the absorbance referring to interaction between cellulose and metal ions. Additionally, absorption band H-C-H at 1440 cm-1 was dramatically decreased which is logically attributed to the redox interaction between cellulose functional groups and metal ions presented in conversion of CH2OH of cellulose to COOH by reduce M +/M+3 to M0. Further decrement in peaks' intensity was properly seen in case of bimetallic nanostructures, indicating homogeneity and alloying. This observation is logically interoperated by greater contribution of cellulosic functional groups in reducing and stabilizing of the so-produced alloyed-bimetallic nanostructures rather than in case of synthesizing uni-metallic nanoparticles. Addition of both of metal salts in the same time is reflected in insignificant changing in absorbance spectral which may be owing to the competition between the different ions in the reduction process. This argumentation is supported by getting considerable wider size distribution and larger size of Ag-Au bimetallic nano-deposits by adding both metal ions in the same moment. Eventually, the data shown in this section confirmed the compatibility of cellulosic solid support in manufacturing both of individual nanoparticles and bimetallic nano-alloys.

sections.heading: Metal and carboxylic contents
sections.text:
Contents of Ag and Au in CSS were evaluated from AAS and EDX, respectively (Table
3). The Au contents data will not be considered owing to the lake in accuracy of EDX results as its evaluation relying on the measurements area and dispersion homogeneity.
The data of Ag contents estimated from AAS for cellulosic substrates deposited with
AgNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy was only considered. It could be significantly observed that Ag content is lowered in cellulosic substrate deposited by nano-alloys rather than that deposited by AgNPs individually as it was ranged in 1.1 – 51.2 g/kg. Through using an equal 1:1 molar ratio of metal salts, addition sequencing greatly affected on Ag content. As when Ag salt was added firstly to the reaction medium, Ag content was estimated to be 43.4 g/kg, while great diminishing of Ag content(1.3 g/kg) was observed in case of adding Au salt firstly to liquor. Subsequently, addition of higher concentrated Au salt firstly also resulted in propagation of alloying but with significant decreasing in Ag content, as 9.9 g/kg was Ag content in case of using Au: Ag mass ratio of 1:0.25. This foundation is logically attributed to the higher electronegativity of Au rather than that of Ag, which might lead to charge transfer from Ag to Au to produce alloyed nanostructures enriched in gold (higher contents of Au than Ag in all bimetallic samples evaluated from EDX is supported this hypothesis).
Terminal alcoholic groups in cellulosic biomolecules are well known with their reducibility
to metal ions. In a redox reaction, metal ions are reduced to nano-sized particles and alcoholic groups in turn oxidized to carboxylic groups (Emam & El-Bisi, 2014; Emam et al., 2016). Subsequently, cellulosic macromolecules with more of carboxylic groups are supposed to complex with metal nanoparticles through their chelating properties for capping and stabilization. Therefore, tracking the change in carboxylic content before and after manufacturing of nanostructures under different experimental conditions, is an important issue.
CSS deposited with nanostructures (either AgNPs or AuNPs or Ag-Au nano bimetallic
nanostructures) exhibited extremely higher carboxylic contents compared to native cellulose, as COOH was dramatically raised from 54.4mmol/kg to 80.9 – 106.0 mmol/kg after nanostructures depositions. This confirmed the redox reaction between cellulosic solid support and metal ions for generating metal nanostructures.
In case of CSS uploaded by monometallic, whatever metal salt concentration used, AuNPs
samples exhibited higher COOH content compared to AgNPs. This may be attributed to the tendency and the difference in redox potentials between Au and Ag, which is in harmony with metal contents and size distribution results. On the other hand, CSS deposited with alloyed/bimetallic nanostructures exhibited higher carboxyl content than monometallic samples which is rationally owing to redox reaction between cellulose and two metals. Compared to addition of Ag salt firstly, greater COOH content obtained by addition of Au salt firstly to the reaction mixture.

sections.heading: Tentative mechanism
sections.text:
Based on the aforementioned results, the extracted powder as cellulosic material was
successfully used in individual fabrication of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy bimetallic nanostructures and template for their direct deposition. The reaction mechanism between metal ions and cellulose was suggested and designed in Figure 6. Cellulose macromolecules employed as nanoparticles generator and protector, as it was described as a template for nanostructures' deposition. Heating of CSS in alkaline medium tended to enhance the reactivity and accessibility of cellulosic macromolecules and consequently the redox reaction with metal ions was improved (Emam & Ahmed, 2016; Emam & El-Bisi, 2014; Emam, Mowafi, et al., 2014; Emam, Saleh, et al., 2015; Emam et al., 2016). Terminal alcoholic groups of cellulosic back bone reduced Ag+1 and Au+3 to Ag0 and Au0, respectively in nano size dimension and turned to carboxylic groups (Emam
& El-Bisi, 2014; Emam, Mowafi, et al., 2014; Emam, Saleh, et al., 2015; Emam et al., 2016). Under basic conditions, hydroxyl groups were de-protonated, and ionic cellulose macromolecules tended to bond with Ag or Au ions via coordinate covalent bond for full reduction and stabilization. Whereas, in case of nano bimetallic formation, the possible interaction can be summarized as follows:
I. In case of adding Ag salt to reaction liquor firstly then followed by Au salt:
 Firstly, Ag was reduced by action of cellulosic macromolecules as mentioned before.
 After Au salt addition, the positive potential of the redox reaction gave rise to a
spontaneous replacement of Ag by Au. However, due to the atomic valence, one Au atom replaces three Ag atoms. This effect is attributed to the fact that the ionization potential and electron affinity values of Au atoms are higher than those of the Ag atoms (Tsai, Chen, Song, Haruta, & Kurata, 2015). The larger electronegativity value of the Au atom leads to effective charge transfer from Ag0 to Au+3.  The resultant AuNPs were then seeded for further reduction of Ag+. The subsequent
co-precipitation of Au and Ag with the assistance of cellulosic functional groups as well as the inter-diffusion of Au and Ag, led to the formation and growth of nanoalloys.
 The inter-particle transfer between Ag and Au atoms resulted in increasing the inter-
particle spacing during alloying, which interoperated the increment in particle size by using higher concentration salt (L. Sun et al., 2012).
i- In case of adding Au salt to reaction liquor firstly then followed by Ag salt:
 When Au salt was added to the reaction liquor, Au+3 reduced to Au0 small nanoclusters
by terminal alcoholic groups of cellulosic substrate.
 By addition of Ag salt, the nearby Ag+1 being co-reduced along with Au+3 on the
surface of Au nanoclusters. Au0 particles supposed to act as seeds or active sites for further growth of Ag0 particles. With extending the heating time, alloyed nanostructures will grow gradually until they reach a size with a surface area that can be stabilized by the surrounding polymers (Roy, Mandal, & Pal, 2003).

sections.heading: Catalytic reduction
sections.text:
Application of the so-obtained mono and bimetallic nanoparticles as catalyst in the
reduction of p-nitro-aniline by sodium borohydride was examined. In this study, five different prepared samples were selected based on preparation conditions including mono and bimetallic, different metals, concentration and sequences of addition. Sample without any addition was used as blank and sample contained CCS was used for negligence the action of cellulose in reduction process.
The reduction process of p-nitro-aniline was followed by measuring the absorbance values
up to 120 minutes and the data diagrammed in Figures 5. During the reduction reaction, p-nitroaniline was transformed to p-phenylene di-amine, and hence the intensity of absorbance band at 380 nm which is signified for p-nitro-aniline was decreased (Pradhan, Pal, & Pal, 2002). Subsequently, a new absorption band characterized for p-phenylene di-amine was appeared at 308 nm and its intensity was raised with reaction time (Figure 7) (Pradhan et al., 2002).
The data diagrammed in Figures 5 showed that, in absence of nanoparticles, absorbance
was marginally decreased by time as it reduced from 2.156 to 1.583 after 2 h. This means that 24.7% only from p-nitro-aniline converted to p-phenylene di-amine by action of sodium borohydride which is quite slow reduction reaction. Presence of cellulose was not affected on the reduction reaction.
By immobilization of the produced nanoparticles, the reduction reaction of p-nitro-aniline
was considerably accelerated as the absorbance values were reduced to 0.621 – 0.123 after 2 h. The reduction of p-nitro-aniline was obviously catalyzed by action of metallic nanoparticles (AgNPs & AuNPs) and bimetallic nano-alloy (Ag-Au).
Compared to monometallic nanoparticles, bimetallic nanostructures exhibited faster
reduction. In case of monometallic nanoparticles (AgNPs & AuNPs), the conversion percentage of p-nitro-aniline to p-phenylene di-amine was 17 – 18% and 71.2 – 75.3% after 20 and 120 minutes, respectively. However, conversion percentage of p-nitro-aniline reached 87.2% through only 20 minutes in case of bimetallic nano-alloy. Size of nano-alloy was found significantly affected on the catalytic reduction of p-nitroaniline and great size of nano-alloy showed much slower reduction reaction comparing to smaller one. As for sample 14, nano-alloy with 638 nm size achieved 80.4% conversion of p-nitro-aniline in two hours, which could be interpreted by the hypothesis of smaller sized nanostructure means higher surface area, which is reflected in higher
reactivity. It could be summarized that immobilization of the produced Ag-Au nano-alloy was quite speeded up the reduction reaction of p-nitro-aniline and 87.2% from p-nitro-aniline was reduced to p-phenylene di-amine in 20 minutes only.
Kinetics of the reduction reaction of p-nitroaniline by sodium borohydride in presence of
the so-obtained nanoparticles, were studied using model of pseudo-first order and data was collected in supplementary data. Rate constant of reaction was extremely enlarged by immobilization of nanoparticles in reaction medium. Values of k was 2.5 x 10-3 m-1 and ranged in 11.6 – 33.7 x 10-3 m-1 in absence and presence of nanoparticles, respectively. Increasing in k value reflects the catalytic activation of nanoparticles in the reaction. Catalytic properties of Ag-Au nano-alloy was observed quite better than monometallic including AgNPs and AuNPs, as K for bimetallic (33.5 – 37.7 x 10-3 m-1) was three times higher than that for monometallic (11.6 – 13.1 x 10-3 m-1). Catalytic action of bimetallic was negatively affected by increment in particle size and k was diminished to 15.9 x 10-3 m-1 by using excessively larger sized bimetallic nano-alloy. Data of the half of reaction time is in harmony with rate constant values as it was significantly decreased in the presence of nanoparticles. Values of t1/2 were dramatically minimized from 277.3 minutes to 18.4 – 20.7 minutes by using Ag-Au nano-alloy as a catalyst. These results summarized that using of 10 mg from the produced Ag-Au nano-alloy helped in full reduction of 122 mg/L p-nitroaniline in 20 minutes by using 15 mM sodium borohydride.
During the preparation of nanoparticles experiments, for samples 1-4, 200 mg/L of metal
(Ag or Au) and 0.2 g CSS were used, and in the catalytic reduction experiments, 10 mg of CSS loaded nanoparticles was used for reduction of 0.2 mM p-nitro-aniline. Hence, the estimated maximum concentration of metals in the catalytic reduction solutions is 0.5 mg for monometallic (samples 1 and 3) and 1.0 mg for bimetallic (samples 2, 4 and 14). by using similar concentration from p-nitro-aniline and sodium borohydride, faster reduction rate was recorded via using AgNPs loaded on glass slide (Zhou et al., 2008). However, the concentration of silver and effect of silicon in glass were not both considered.
Comparing with the catalytic reduction of p-nitro-phenol (Gangula, Podila, Karanam,
Janardhana, & Rao, 2011), rapid reduction was recorded by using quite high concentration of AgNPs (5.35 – 21.4 mg) and AuNPs (9.9 – 19.7 mg) in reduction of 0.2 mM p-nitro-phenol, which is higher 5 – 20 times than concentration used in the current study. Moreover, much bigger sized
monometallic particles (20 – 100 nm for AgNPs and 10 – 50 nm for AuNPs) were applied compared to that currently used.
Ag(I)-gelatine complex was prepared over silica gel and used to release AgNPs as a catalyst
for reduction of p-nitro-phenol (Kundu, Mandal, Ghosh, & Pal, 2004). A 5.3 mg of the complex loaded silver was catalysed p-nitro-phenol by using similar concentrations from the reducer (NaBH4). Faster reduction rate was monitored by using AgNPs (16.0 ± 4.0 nm) (Kundu et al., 2004), which could be related to presence of gelatine and silica gel that may play a role in the activation of reduction reaction.
Despite of using slightly higher concentrations of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloys
(1 – 2 mg) in reduction reaction of p-nitro-phenol with quite high concentration of NaBH4 (30 mM), the results obtained here for bimetallic was much better compared to that reported by K. S. Shin et al. (Wunder, Polzer, Lu, Mei, & Ballauff, 2010). Much slower reduction reaction was recorded by using AgNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy. The obtained rate constants were 6.10 x 10-3 s-1 and 1.6 x 10-2 for AgNPs and Au-Ag nano-alloy respectively, which are significantly lower than those obtained in the current study. Based on these comparable study, the current work offered that, low concentrations from the so-obtained Ag-Au nano-alloy showed quite good catalytic reduction results.
The catalytic activity of the produced nanoparticles (mono/bimetallic) in the reduction of
p-nitro-aniline using of sodium borohydride can be explained as follows: BH4 - is reducing agent which electron rich, acting as electron donating (hydrogen supplier) reagent. The huge potential difference between donor (NaBH4) and acceptor (p-nitro-aniline) diminishes the feasibility of the reduction reaction (Edison & Sethuraman, 2013; Wunder et al., 2010). In presence of nanoparticles including AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy, p-nitro-aniline firstly adsorbs on the surface of nanoparticles. Then reduction reaction was supposed to be catalyzed by facilitating the electrons transfer from BH4 − to p-nitro-aniline through the uploaded nanostructures (Gangula et al., 2011; D. Huang, Yang, Feng, Lai, & Zhao, 2015; Zhou et al., 2008). Moreover, BH4 − can also transports hydrogen species to nanostructures, and then transformed to p-nitro-aniline immediately. Owing to the diffusion, the product separates from the catalyst surface (nanoparticles) (Gangula et al., 2011; Zhou et al., 2008).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The current study hereof has successfully demonstrated a facile, efficient, eco-friendly
«green» and inexpensive approach for one-pot fabrication of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nanoalloyed individually using plant extract as cellulosic solid supporting (CSS) template. Cellulosic macromolecules successfully played role of nanoparticles' generator and protector from aggregation. Size of nano-alloy can be controlled by tuning the metal salts concentration, molar ratios of nanometal precursors and their sequences of addition and varied from 9.5 nm (5-20 nm) to 40.0 nm (24-52 nm). In case of monometallic nanoparticles, smaller sized AuNPs (26.1 nm) was obtained compared to AgNPs (36.3 nm). Carboxylic contents for cellulosic reactor before and after the reaction with metal precursors were evaluated and confirmed that metal ions were reduced to metallic form through employing the alcoholic groups of CSS, which in turn were oxidized to carboxylic groups. Catalytic activity of the so-obtained nanoparticles (AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy) was performed for reduction of p-nitro-aniline using sodium borohydride. Reduction reaction was greatly accelerated by action of nanoparticles and conversion of p-nitro-aniline to pphenylene di-amine was attained 87.2% in 20 minutes in presence of bimetallic nano-alloy prepared using equal mass ratio from metal precursors. For the same sample, the highest catalytic rate constant was (37.7 x 10-3 m-1) recorded and significantly decreased (15.9 x 10-3 m-1) by enlargement in size of nano-alloy to 638 nm. Monometallic nanostructures exhibited lower catalytic rates relative to bimetallic ones.
Eventually, this work provides a simple route for one-pot fabrication of monometallic
nanoparticles and bimetallic nano-alloy on the surface of cellulose solid support. Final products of AgNPs, AuNPs and Ag-Au nano-alloy loaded cellulose in solid form can be easily handled for many applications. Additionally, these products confirmed their great potential in the catalysis field as a good catalyst. Moreover, such an eco-friendly synthetic strategy can be extended for manufacturing a wide variety of other nano-composites than the presented (Au-Ag) one, which is expected to be of great importance for further applications.

metadata.abstractText: The current report provides a simple, green and inexpensive route for one-pot fabrication of AgNPs, AuNPs, and Ag-Au nano-alloy individually onto cellulosic solid support. Cellulosic solid support was naturally extracted from plant and then was used for deposition of nanoparticles. The manufacturing was carried out through redox reaction between metal ions and alcoholic groups of cellulose, resulting in production of metallic/bimetallic nanostructures. AuNPs was obtained in size of 26.1 nm smaller than AgNPs (36.3 nm). Controlling in size of bimetallic nanostructures was achieved by tuning the concentrations, mass ratios of nanometal precursors and their addition sequencing in reaction liquor. Immobilization of nanoparticles/bimetallic nanostructures was frequently speeded up the reduction reaction of p-nitro-aniline, however,
